DataElement.preferredName: Person Saccharomyces Cerevisiae Hypersensitivity Skin Testing Date
DataElement.preferredDefinition: Calendar date on which a person had a skin test for S. cerevisiae (Baker's Yeast) hypersensitivity.

DataElementConcept.preferredName: Person Saccharomyces Cerevisiae Hypersensitivity Skin Testing
DataElementConcept.preferredDefinition: A person's experience of a hypersensitivity/allergic response to the adminstration of an agent; a reaction can range from mild dermatologic or hypertensive signs to acute anaphylaxis._A species of the genus SACCHAROMYCES, family Saccharomycetaceae, order Saccharomycetales, known as "baker's" or "brewer's" yeast. The dried form is used as a dietary supplement._A local or general reaction of an organism following contact with a specific allergen to which it has been previously exposed and to which it has become sensitized._A preparation of an antigenic component of an infectious agent that is administered to a patient in order to determine whether previous exposure to the agent has occurred, and/or to assess the integrity of the patient's cellular immune system.  Depending on the clinical situation, the appearance of a delayed (cellular) hypersensitivity response, which manifests as an area of induration and erythema at the injection site, i.e. a positive test result, may indicate previous exposure to a particular infectious agent. (NCI04)

ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: Person; a human being.:A species of unicellular fungus used as a research subject and in baking and beer brewing.:A local or general reaction of an organism following contact with a specific allergen to which it has been previously exposed and to which it has become sensitized.

Concepts.definition: A species of unicellular fungus used as a research subject and in baking and beer brewing.
An immune response that occurs following exposure to an innocuous antigen, but that does not require the presence of preformed antibodies to the antigen.

Property.preferredDefinition: A preparation of an antigenic component of an infectious agent that is administered to a patient in order to determine whether previous exposure to the agent has occurred, and/or to assess the integrity of the patient's cellular immune system.  Depending on the clinical situation, the appearance of a delayed (cellular) hypersensitivity response, which manifests as an area of induration and erythema at the injection site, i.e. a positive test result, may indicate previous exposure to a particular infectious agent. (NCI04)

Concepts.definition: A preparation of an antigenic component of an infectious agent that is administered to a patient in order to determine whether previous exposure to the agent has occurred, and/or to assess the integrity of the patient's cellular immune system.  Depending on the clinical situation, the appearance of a delayed (cellular) hypersensitivity response, which manifests as an area of induration and erythema at the injection site, i.e. a positive test result, may indicate previous exposure to a particular infectious agent. (NCI04)

ConceptualDomain.preferredDefinition: Tests, examinations, evaluations used to determine a subject's status or response to intervention.
ConceptualDomain.changeDescription: Created initially to support CCR value domain for CTMS.

ValueDomain.preferredDefinition: Date as required for Clinical Trials Monitoring Service submissions.  Exchange format is YYYYMMDD.  Display format is DDMMMYYYY, with the month display the first three letters of each month (Jan, Feb, Mar, etc.).

RepresentationTerm.preferredDefinition: a particular day specified as the time something has, or will, happen.

Concepts.definition: The particular day, month and year an event has happened or will happen.

ValueDomain.changeDescription: 8/30/17 jk Transferred context, added CSI and reg status, released per Round 5 finalization task. --- Display and exchange formats are based on CTMS reporting requirements v.3.02 and all subsequent versions of these guidelines.

DataElement.changeDescription: Curated to support Univ Arkansas Medical Services adoption of C3D.
